How joyful and pleaſed were we both when you awoke! You would run, ſhaking your tail, under the ſopha and under the chairs and tables, and then jump from one to the other. How happy did you appear when I took you in my lap! How you would li • k my hands and face, and play with me! Oh! how ſorry ſhall I be if I never ſee you again! Ah! I ſhould never have loſt you myſelf; but that careleſs—

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I ſee, my name is called in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Ay, whoſe elſe ſhould it be? If you had not been ſo poſitive in taking her out with you yeſterday, ſhe would not have been loſt.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: That is true, and I am as ſorry for it as you are: but what can I do now?

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Did I not beg of you to leave her at home? but you could not go a ſtep without having her at your heels.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I own it. I was ſo pleaſed when ſhe was along with me, to ſee her walk ſometimes before me, and ſometimes behind me. Then ſhe would run from me as if I was purſuing her, and come back again at full ſpeed, and jump up about me ſo playful.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Then you ſhould have taken better care of her.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhould ſo. But as ſhe uſed to go away from me, and come back of herſelf without any occaſion for my calling her, I thought—

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: You thought?—you have never the leaſt miſtruſt of any thing; and by that poor Diana was loſt.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I promiſe you, ſiſter, the next time—

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Yes, another time when we have nothing to loſe. I could not ſleep a quarter of an hour together all laſt night. I thought I heard her whining to me at a diſtance, and that I ran to the ſide from which her cries ſeemed to come. Then I awoke, and found myſelf alone. Ah! I dare ſay ſhe is as dull too, for her part.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Dear ſiſter, it makes me doubly unhappy to ſee you grieve ſo. I would give all that I am worth in the world to have her again.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Now you make me grieve ſtill more. Why, don't you know at leaſt where you miſſed her? One might enquire amongſt all the neighbours thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I'd lay a wager ſhe followed me into this ſtreet, and almoſt as far as our own houſe too. But as ſhe runs up into every court ſmelling about, ſomebody muſt have ſhut their door upon her and kept her in.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Yes, I dare ſay it was ſo; otherwiſe ſhe would have come back to her lodging. She knows the way to it well enough.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Lionel was along with me, and declared to me that he ſaw her but the moment before we miſſed her. And it was his fault; for he was playing ſuch comical tricks as we walked along, that I forgot Diana juſt then.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Well, he ſhould have helped you at leaſt to look for her.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: So he did all yeſterday evening, and to-day again very early. We went into all the ſtreets and lanes round about, and ſearched every court and market near us. We enquired, in ſhort, among all our acquaintances, but could hear nothing of her. Indeed, ſiſter, I am aſhamed to look you in the face. I know you muſt be angry with me.

sp.speaker: Serina,
sp.p: No, I am not angry now. You did not mean to diſoblige me; and beſides, you are ſo ſorry yourſelf! But who is this coming up ſtairs? Go and ſee.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: It is I, it is I, Euſtace. Good morning to you, Miſs Serina.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Good morning, Maſter Lionel.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: I have got a ſcent of Diana, and I hope pretty ſoon—

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: What? to find her again?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: I'll tell you. You know that old woman that lives at the corner of the ſtreet, and ſells cakes and garden ſtuff?

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: What? has ſhe my little dog?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: No, no; ſhe is a very honeſt woman, and a good friend of mine. You know, Euſtace, that Diana too wanted t'other day to ſcrape acquaintance with her, ſtanding up with her paws upon the counter, and ſmelling at the biſcuits.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Ah! yes; but her little fond tricks would not do there, for the old woman gave her a great ſtroke on the noſe with her glove.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Oh! that is nothing. Well, Maſter Lionel?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Well, juſt now I went to her ſhop to buy ſome cakes, and was telling her of our loſs. What, ſays ſhe, that little cur dog?—

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Cur dog, Maſter Lionel? Don't call my pretty Diana ſo. I would rather not hear you talk of her at all.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p:
Nay, I only tell you her own words. That little cur dog, ſays ſhe, that belongs to that pretty young gentleman, your acquaintance? Yes, ſaid I, the ſame. Well, you know another little maſter that lives here below,
at the large houſe with the balcony? It was he that coaxed her away.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: How? could ſhe mean Rufus?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Don't you remember that he was at the old woman's ſhop yeſterday as we paſſed, and pretended not to ſee us, for fear of being obliged to offer us ſome of his walnuts?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: That is very true. I recollect it now.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Well, when we had paſt her houſe a little way, he called Diana as ſhe was following us, and offered her a bit of cake, and while the poor thing was buſy feaſting herſelf, he ſnatched her up in his arms and carried her home. The good woman told me the whole trick.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: An ill-natured creature! well, however, we know where ſhe is. Brother, you had better go to him without any more ado.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: I am greatly afraid that he would not find her there. Rufus has taken her only to ſell her, as he does his books and whatever elſe he can purloin at his father's. He is capable of any thing. Why, we were playing at marbles t'other day, and he cheated.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Ay • is that his way? I'll run to him this moment.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: You will not find him at home. I have juſt been there, and he was out.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Perhaps he bid them ſay that he was not at home.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: No; I went up to his room, and I told the maid that I wanted him to come and play at marbles, and that I would wait for him at your houſe.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: He will never have the face to ſhew himſelf here, if he has really taken Diana.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Ah! you do not know his aſſurance. He would come here on purpoſe, that you might not ſuſpect him; but I'll convict him before you.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: We muſt go cunningly to work and queſtion him ſlily, to make him diſcover the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: I'll tell you. All the cunning required is to ſhew him at the firſt word that he is a rogue and a thief.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: No, no, my dear Lionel, that would only b • ing on a quarrel, and my papa would not have any here. Mild words, perhaps, will touch him better than reproaches or violence.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Perhaps too he does not know that the little greyhound is ours.

sp.speaker: Lionel
sp.p: Not know, does not he ſee her along with your brother every day? he has played with her a hundred times, and ſtole her yeſterday to ſell her. That is juſt his character.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Hiſt! here he comes.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: They told me at home, Lionel, that you wanted me to play at marbles. Come, I am ready. Ah! Euſtace, how do you do? Your humble ſervant, miſs.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: You are going to your diverſion, Maſter Rufus, Nothing gives you uneaſineſs; but we are all in trouble here.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: What is the matter then?

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: We have loſt our pretty little greyhound.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: Dear! that is a pity! ſhe was a pretty little creature, indeed. Her body ſo handſome; a gre • with black ſpots here and there, and her breaſt and forefeet and tail all white. She is worth two guineas, if ſhe is worth a farthing.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: You know her ſo well! could not you help us to f • d her again?

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: Do you take me for a dog-keeper? or am I obliged to look after yours?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: My ſiſter did not mean to affront you, Rufus.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Oh dear! no. It was only a civil queſtion. As you live in our neighbourhood and ſhe was loſt not far off, I thought that you might have been able to give us ſome account of her.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Certainly, you could not apply to a better perſon.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: What do you mean by that, Maſter Lionel?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: What is beſt known to yourſelf; though I am perfectly acquainted too with the whole affair.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: If it were not out of reſpect to miſs—

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: You ſhould thank her yourſelf, that I do not chaſtiſe you for your impudence.

sp.speaker: Euſtace,
sp.p: Softly, my dear Lionel, or we ſhall loſe the greyhound.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: If, as you ſay, you have ſome regard for me, Maſter Rufus, be ſo good as to hear me attentively, and anſwer me, yes or no.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: And without ſhuffling.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Have not you our greyhound? or don't you know where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Rufus,
sp.p: I? I your greyhound?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Do you ſtammer at the queſtion? you have her. And I know the whole ſtory too. You took her treacherouſly, coaxing her with a bit of cake.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: Who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: One that ſaw you do it.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: I aſk it as a favour of you, Maſter Rufus, to tell me is that true or falſe?

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: And ſuppoſe I did give your dog a bit of cake, or that I took her up a moment to play with her, is that a reaſon that I ſhould have her, or know what is become of her?

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Nor do we ſay ſo. We only aſk you if you know where ſhe is juſt now.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Or if you did not keep her at your houſe laſt night out of a frolick, to frighten us a little, and afterwards to give us the pleaſure of a ſurprize?

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: What, do you take our houſe for a dog-kennel?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: He muſt have a vaſt deal of aſſurance!

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: I have nothing to ſay to you. You may be counſellor f • r greyhounds as long as you will, I won't be examined by you.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Becauſe I have confounded you.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Softly, Maſter Lionel, you muſt be miſtaken. I cannot ſuſpect Maſter Rufus of ſo much meanneſs as to keep our dog if he had found it.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: If he had loſt any thing, and I could give him an account of it, I would do it with pleaſure. So he need not be angry at our queſtions.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: I am very angry at them, and I will make a complaint of it to your father.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: You had better come to the cake-woman's houſe; I will go along with you.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: It is very pretty of you, to believe ſuch a prating goſſip before me.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Such goſſips, however, have eyes and ears, and, as far as honeſty is concerned, I ſhould truſt them ſooner than you.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: I won't put up with this affront, and you ſhall pay for it. (He goes out.)

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: What an impudent liar! I would lay my life that he has the dog. Did not you ſee how he was confounded when I told him flatly that he had her?

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: I cannot believe it yet, and indeed it would be quite too ſcandalous.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: You cannot believe it, miſs, becauſe your own heart is ſo good; for my part I can believe any thing of him.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: I muſt own, however, that it was very rude not to anſwer our queſtions civilly.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: If you had not been here, miſs, I would have tweaked him by the ears a little.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Tut, man, he is taller than you by the head.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: If he was twice as tall, I'll wager he is a coward. Did not you obſerve that he grew more impudent as we were more civil? and the harder I puſhed him, the quieter he became. But I'll go and follow him and take Diana from him, wherever he has put her.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Your pains would be to no purpoſe, maſter Lionel. Once more, I cannot believe it. He lives too near us, to expect to hide ſuch a theft from us.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I hope he may not go and kill her, for fear of being found out in a lie.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: No, my friend, he won't kill her. He keeps her for ſale.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: O heavens! what an opinion you have of him!

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: It is ſuch as he deſerves, and I'll go and convince you of it.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Lionel is too hot. He makes a terrible quarrel of the ſmalleſt difference. If they muſt wrangle, I am glad at leaſt that it is not here.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: For then, papa would give us a fine leſſon. Lionel, I believe, is willing to ſerve us; but I am ſorry that he ſeems to ſeek his own revenge more than our advantage.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: He deſires no better than to be in every quarrel, and he has done us more harm than good. If Rufus really ſtole Diana, he would return her to me ſooner for good words than for threats. But here comes papa.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: What have you done to Rufus? He came to me as I was in my room, and ſeemed quite ruffled. He complains of you very much, but particularly of Lionel, and ſays that you accuſe him of ſtealing Diana. Is ſhe loſt?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Ah! yes, papa. I did not like to tell you, becauſe I hoped every moment to find her again. She went aſtray from me yeſterday evening.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Ah! you cannot imagine how ſorry I am for her. I cried the beſt part of laſt night, when I awoke and miſſed her from my ſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Luckily, it is but a dog. Loſſes of much more conſequence happen every day in the world, and we ſhould early accuſtom ourſelves to bear with them. But you, (to Euſtace) why did not you take care of her?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: You are very right, papa. It was my fault. I ſhould have left her at home, or elſe not have loſt ſight of her, ſince I took her in my charge. And I am ſorry for it eſpecially, on account of my ſiſter, becauſe Diana was hers more than mine.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: I cannot be angry with my brother for it. I have ſometimes vexed him without intention, and he has excuſed me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Kiſs me, my dear child; I love to ſee you bear a misfortune with courage; but I am ſtill better pleaſed to ſee you, in the midſt of your grief, not the leaſt provoked againſt him that occaſioned it.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: My poor brother is ſufficiently puniſhed for his negligence, for he was as fond of Diana as I. She was all his amuſement; and he grieves, beſides, that he was the occaſion of my uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Always preſerve theſe ſentiments, my dear children, one towards the other, and indeed towards all your fellow-creatures, for they are of the ſame family. I know many perſons who, for ſuch a trifle, would have turned away an honeſt ſervant.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Oh! heaven forbid! Prefer a dog to a ſervant? A creature without reaſon to a perſon of our own kind?

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Why do not all men make that difference as well as you, my dear child? We ſhould not then know thoſe who would rather ſee a poor child ſuffer hunger or thirſt than a favourite dog; who ſhed tears at the indiſpoſition of a ſpaniel, and look without pity on the lot of an unhappy orphan abandoned by all the world.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: papa! is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: In return for the ſentiment which draws that generous ſigh from your breaſt, I promiſe you, my dear, a greyhound as handſome as the one that you have loſt, if you are not lucky enough to find her again.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: No, papa, I thank you. I have ſuffered too much from the loſs of Diana. If ſhe does not come back, I will never have another. I will not run the riſque of grieving ſo again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: You carry things too far, my dear Serina. In that caſe we muſt reſign all the moſt agreeable pleaſures of life. We ſhould be afraid to love a friend, becauſe death or abſence might one day ſeparate us from him. If you compare the pleaſure which Diana's playful fondneſs has afforded you ever ſince ſhe was born, to the ſhort uneaſineſs that her loſs occaſions to you now, the firſt you will find exceeds the ſecond by a great deal. Nothing is more natural than to be fond of a pretty little creature, like Diana; and indeed, it would be a mark of ingratitude in you—

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Yes, if I did not think of her now, becauſe ſhe is not here to play about me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: What comforts me a little in this misfortune is, that from this you will be better enabled to bear perhaps a greater. Every thing that we poſſeſs upon earth may ſlip from our hands with the ſame readineſs, and it is wiſe to accuſtom ourſelves early to the moſt ſevere loſſes. But, with regard to our firſt ſubject of converſation, you have treated Rufus ill, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Not we, papa; we ſpoke to him very mildly. It was Lionel that touched him cloſe a little.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: And what did he ſay in anſwer?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: He defended himſelf but lamely. Indeed he was quite out of countenance at the firſt queſtion.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: But now I will aſk you, papa, do you think that he could have the aſſurance to deny it, if he had really taken my greyhound?

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: I can ſay nothing as to that; but, I ſhould think, his confuſion could not come from a very clear conſcience. However, that we may have no reproach to make to ourſelves, concerning Diana, we muſt advertiſe her to-morrow in the public papers.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: But, papa, if ſhe is really in his power, that trouble will be uſeleſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: No, it cannot be uſeleſs. A dog requires to be fed, and is not ſo ſmall or ſo quiet that one can hide it from every body's eyes. There may happen to be ſome perſon in his houſe honeſt enough to give us information of it. I will not apply to his father, I know his rude manners too well. Beſides, he is offended with me for forbidding you a too cloſe intimacy with his ſon. We muſt wait to ſee what our advertiſement will produce.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: I ſhould have ſome hopes from it, if I were able to promiſe a large reward to whoever would bring me back the dog.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: I ſhall take care of that. Come, Euſtace, into my cloſet; we will put down her deſcription, and you ſhall take it to the printing-office.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Oh! what joy it would be for the poor little creature, and for me too, to ſee each other once more!

sp.speaker: Euſtace,
sp.p: Siſter! Siſter!

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: What is the matter? You ſeem to be in high ſpirits. Is Diana found?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Diana? Oh! ſomething much better. See, (ſhewing a ring in a ſmall caſe.) look at what I have found not a yard from our door.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Oh! the charming ring! But the ſtone that ſhould be in the middle, where is that?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it had fallen out. See here it is in a paper. Look at this diamond in the light. See how it ſparkles! My papa's brilliant is not ſo large.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: I pity him very much that has loſt it.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: It is worſe than to loſe a greyhound.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Oh! I don't know that. My little Diana was ſo pretty, and ſo fond of us. And then we had her a whelp. Oh! when I think how happy we were to ſee her learn new tricks as ſhe grew bigger, and to amuſe ourſelves with her play, the fineſt ring that ever I could put on my finger would not make me half ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: But with this ring you might buy a hundred grey hounds like her.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: It ſhould not buy mine, for all that. He that loſt the ring has others, perhaps, and I had only my poor Diana. I am worſe off than he is.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: It muſt belong to a rich man. Poor people have not ſuch toys as this.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Yet if it was ſome unfortunate ſervant that loſt it, in taking it to the jeweller—or if it was the jeweller himſelf; the diamond being looſe would make one ſuſpect ſo; what a misfortune it would be for the poor people!

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: You are right. Well, now I am quite out of humour with my prize. We muſt aſk papa's advice about it. Oh! this is lucky! here he comes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Well, will the advertiſement for your greybound be in to-morrow's paper?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Papa, I have not been at the office yet. Here is what kept me. A ring that I have found. (Gives him the caſe.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: A very fine diamond, indeed.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: An't it? This is enough to put a little dog out of one's head for a moment or two.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Yes, if it were your own. Do you intend to keep it?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Why, if nobody makes inquiry about it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Did any body ſee you take it up?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: No, papa.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: For my part, I ſhould never reſt until I knew who owned it.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Let the owner ſhew himſelf, and certainly the ring ſhall not ſtay long in my hands. No, that would be as bad as if I had ſtolen it. We muſt give every one his own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: You will not be, perhaps, ſo well pleaſed then?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Why not, papa? I own, I did not think of any thing at firſt but my good luck in finding ſuch a jewel. I looked upon it as already my property: but my ſiſter has given me an idea of the trouble that he muſt feel who loſt it. I ſhould be much happier in putting an end to his uneaſineſs, than in keeping this ring, which would make me bluſh every time that I looked at it.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: There is ſo much pleaſure in comforting thoſe who are troubled. For that reaſon, I cannot imagine that Rufus or any other could be ſo ill-natured as to keep my Diana, if he knew how ſorry I am for her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Amiable little innocents! My dear children, how I rejoice in being your father! Let ſuch generous ſentiments continue to ſpring up and gain ſtrength in your hearts. They will be the foundation of your own happineſs and that of your fellow-creatures.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: You give us the example, papa. How ſhould we have other ſentiments?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Oh! I'll go and ſhew my prize to every body; and we ſhould advertiſe both together in the papers, that we have loſt a greyhound and found a ring.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt, my dear; there are precautions to be taken. There might be ſome people who would claim the ring, without being the owners.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Oh! I ſhould be as cunning as they. I would aſk them firſt how it was made, and I would not give it to any but him that told me very particularly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: That way is not the ſureſt, neither. A perſon may have ſeen it upon the owner's finger, and come here before him to demand it.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Ah! papa, I ſee you know better how to manage than we do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: The loſer will think it worth while to make every enquiry after ſo valuable an article. So we muſt wait.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: But if they ſhould not think of doing ſo?

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: We thought of doing ſo for Diana; certainly others will for a diamond.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Meanwhile I ſhall take care of it; and do you be cautious not to ſpeak of it to any body.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: It is very ſtupid, for all that, not to be able to talk, when one has any thing ſo agreeable to tell. I ſhould have been ſo happy to ſhew every body my ring!

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: And why, ſince you neither can, nor would keep it? There is no great merit in finding any thing valuable in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: That is true; but what I tell you is very true too.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: People ſay of the ladies, that they cannot keep a ſecret. Let us ſee which of us two will be moſt diſcreet.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: For fear my ſecret ſhould want to eſcape, I will think of nothing but Diana; and now I'll go to the printing-office with the advertiſement.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Go, brother; do not loſe a moment. But what does Lionel want with us?

sp.speaker: Lionel,
sp.p: Where are you going, Euſtace?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I have ſomething particular to do.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Oh! before you go, you muſt liften to a ſtory that I have to tell you. It will make you die with laughing. Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I have not time for laughing now.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: You will laugh in ſpite of yourſelf. Only liſten. We have got full ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Full ſatisfaction? Of whom?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Of Rufus. He has loſt his father's ring. Ha, ha, ha, ha! (Euſtace and Serina look at each other with an air of ſurprize.)

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: His father's ring?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: It is fact. He had it given to him this morning to take to the jeweller's, to have the middle diamond ſet in again, that had fallen out. (Euſtace jogs Serina; ſhe makes a ſign to him to be ſilent.) He had it when he came here; but as he went away, quite fluſtered with anger, the caſe of the ring muſt have dropt out of his pocket as he whiſked along.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: And have you ſeen him ſince he loſt it? How does he look?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Frightened out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Does his father know it?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: There he has drawn himſelf into a freſh ſcrape, by telling a great fib. When his father aſked him if he had given the ring to the jeweller, he anſwered, with the greateſt aſſurance, that he had.

sp.speaker: Scrina.
sp.p: Unhappy creature!

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Why you pity him, do you?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Indeed he is to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: He? I wiſh you had ſeen what game I made of him.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: What did you find ſo comical in all that?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p:
How? don't you take the jeſt? To ſee him running from ſhop to ſhop, inquiring about his ring, and plucking every one by the ſkirt that paſſed. I ſtuck cloſe to him, to enjoy his diſtreſs, and at laſt he came up to
me: "Have not you found it? Have you heard nothing of it?" What is it to me? ſaid I to him. Am I your ring-keeper?—"If you knew what it was worth!" So much the better for him that has found it. "And then my father, what will he ſay?" Why, he'll talk to you with a good ſtick.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Fie! maſter Lionel, that was very cruel of you.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: He had not more feeling for you.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Should we be ill-natured then, even towards thoſe that are ſo themſelves?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Oh! revenge is ſweet, and I never have any compaſſion for them that offend me. If I had the good luck to find his ring, he ſhould not have it ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Would you keep it then?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Oh! no. I would give it to him after his father had threſhed him well.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I ſhould never have thought you ſo ill-natured, Lionel.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: And I cannot believe it, though I hear it from his own mouth. You were ſo much concerned about my poor greyhound. It ſeems, it was not in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: It was from the bottom of my heart. I love thoſe dearly, that I do love; but when I hate any one, I hate him heartily.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Heh! there he comes. (Points at him with his finger.) Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: Oh! pray now forgive me. I have been very bad, to be ſure, but I have been full as unfortunate. I am puniſhed now, and well puniſhed too, for—

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Have you ſtuck up hand-bills concerning your ring?

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: I dare not appear before my father, and I don't know where to hide myſelf.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: I would lay a wager that the ring is hanging at Diana's tail. We ſhall find them both together.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: I have deſerved your jeers; but, for pity's ſake—

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Make yourſelf eaſy, maſter Rufus; your ring is here.

sp.speaker: Rufus,
sp.p: What, have you it? You my ring?

sp.speaker: Lionel,
sp.p: He is making game of him: that is right.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: But is it really ſo? Oh! on my knees I'll— But no—you ſhall firſt hear how wicked I have been.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: What is the meaning of that? He is gone off.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: I am afraid the poor boy has loſt his wits.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Your joke, for all that, may coſt you dear. If he goes and fetches his father to demand the ring?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Do you think then that I will keep it?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Why, have you actually the ring?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Certainly I have it, otherwiſe I ſhould not have ſaid ſo. I picked it up cloſe by our door.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Indeed you are too good. He does not deſerve to be ſo happy. You ſhould have left him a little longer in pain, at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: How, maſter Lionel? Does not my brother's example move you? Do you know that you loſe ground now very much, in his friendſhip and mine?

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: What is the matter with Rufus? I ſaw him from my window, come in here all in tears.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: The poor boy was half dead.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: It was he who loſt the ring that I found. It belongs to his father.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Have you convinced him of the meanneſs of his behaviour towards us?

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Dear ſir, no. Diana has not been ſo much as mentioned.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: At leaſt I would have inſiſted upon his returning her. He ſhould not hear of his ring without that.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Ah! papa, my heart would not let me be ſo harſh. I ſaw Rufus ſo afflicted.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: Though I love Diana very well, I could not poſſibly think of her juſt then, nor of any thing but the grief of that unfortunate boy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: You have both acted generouſly, and you are my dear children, my beſt friends, all my joy and all my pride. None but baſe ſouls would inſult the diſtreſs of an enemy that is fallen. But where is Rufus? Why did not he aſk for the ring as he went away?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: He was ſo tranſported with joy, that he did not know what he was doing.

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: He ran towards the door, and went out as if he were mad.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: O! papa, did you but know how overjoyed I am to ſee you approve my behaviour, and my ſiſter's!

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: Could you believe me inſenſible to a generous action?

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: Becauſe you had forbidden me—

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: I forbad you to ſpeak unguardedly about the ring, but I did not tell you to keep it, when the owner ſhould appear.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Mr. Calvert, Serina, Euſtace, Lionel, Rufus (having the greyhound under his arm.)

sp.speaker: Serina,
sp.p: Ah! Diana! my dear Diana! (She runs to her, takes her up in her arms, and careſſes her.)

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: You ſee how much I was to blame, and how little I deſerved your generoſity. Can you pardon me this fraud, and my unworthy behaviour? (Perceiving Mr. Calvert.) Ah! ſir, how bad I muſt appear in your eyes!

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: A perſon is no longer ſo when he acknowledges his fault, and endeavours, as you do, to repair it. Here is your father's ring.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: I am aſhamed and ſorry to have offended ſo excellent children. What difference between them and me! How wicked I am, and how generous are they!

sp.speaker: Serina.
sp.p: It is only a little prank of yours, Maſter Rufus, and you would not have let the day paſs without returning Diana to me.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: You think too well of me. I had hid her up in the garret, and—

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p:
We don't wiſh to know any more. It is ſufficient that you are ſorry for what you have done. You
now ſee yourſelf, that bad actions make God and man our enemies, and are always diſcovered ſooner or later. I ſhould take the liberty too of propoſing to you as a model, the behaviour of my children, generous little creatures! How ſhould I thank Heaven for ſending me ſuch a gif • ! You ſee, the moſt noble and certain revenge is that of doing kindneſſes, and that nothing is more worthy a great ſpirit, than to repay ill-nature with good offices.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: Ah! I feel that now myſelf with the moſt lively ſorrow. (To Euſtace and Serina.) Will you ever forgive me?

sp.speaker: Euſtace,
sp.p: Yes, from this moment, and ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Serina
sp.p: I have my Diana once more, and all is forgot.

sp.speaker: Rufus,
sp.p: We ſhould be unworthy of this pattern if we did not follow it.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: I am as much aſhamed as you, and this leſſon ſhall not be loſt on me.

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: I have juſt confeſſed all to my father. In proportion as he was angry with me, he was touched with your generoſity. He requeſts permiſſion to come in about an hour hence, to thank you and to beg your acceptance of a ſmall token of his gratitude.

sp.speaker: Mr. Calv.
sp.p: No, there is no occaſion for any preſents. To do well, my children deſire no reward but from themſelves. Beſides, reſtoring a perſon his property is no more than a ſtrict duty.

sp.speaker: Euſtace.
sp.p: How pleaſing to perform that duty! I have gained a friend for my whole life; have not I, Rufus?

sp.speaker: Rufus.
sp.p: If I could be worthy of that honour. I ſhall do every thing in my power to be ſo.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.p: Do not exclude me from your friendſhip. I was no better than Rufus; but I have juſt now felt how noble a paſſion revenge may be made.

sp.speaker: Serina,
sp.p: Ah! little runaway! this will teach you another time to ſtray from your maſters: you have paſſed a night in priſon for it. Offer to do ſo again, and you'll ſee!—Well, what would be the conſequence? Ah! no, whatever you do, I find I ſhall always be fond of you.

div.head: THE HEN.
div.p: HOW happy was Cyprian in ſo worthy and affectionate a father as Mr. Tiſdall. Whenever he had ſhown himſelf for any length of time diſcreet and diligent, he was aſſured that his father would not fail to teſtify his ſatisfaction with ſome recompence or other. Cyprian had a taſte for gardening, and began, about the age of twelve, to cultivate choice flowers. His father ſaw it, and immediately began to ſtudy how he might afford his ſon more pleaſure.

They were both at dinner. Cyprian, ſaid his father, your preceptor has informed me, that you have begun this very day to read the Roman Hiſtory, and the Geography of Italy. If, in a week, you can but give me an exact account of every thing you may have learned on theſe two ſubjects, you cannot think what I intend ſhall recompence your application!

Cyprian, one may eaſily ſuppoſe, did not forget ſuch a promiſe. He employed himſelf in ſtudying all the week, to get this recompence; or rather, he received ſuch pleaſure from his ſtudy, that indeed it was he who ſhould have beſtowed a recompence on his Papa if he had been able.

He ſaw the day of trial come, without anxiety; and underwent the examination like an hero. He had learned the hiſtory of all the kings of Rome, and marked out in his map the gradual progreſs of that growing empire.

In a tranſport of delight, his father took him by the hand, embraced and kiſſed him. Come, ſays he, ſince you have ſought to give me ſo much pleaſure, it is but juſt that I ſhould contribute in my turn to yours. Saying this, he led him into an adjoining garden, pointed out a vacant ſpot to him, and told him that it was to be his. You may part it in two, continued he; and plant what flowers you like in one, and any vegetables that you think proper in the other. After this, they went into an out-houſe, cloſe behind the gardener's hut, where Cyprian found a ſpade, a watering-pot, a rake, and other implements of gardening, all perfectly adapted to his ſize and ſtrength. On the walls were baſkets hung up, of every ſize, great and ſmall,
and on ſhelves about them, ſundry boxes full of roots, and bags of ſeeds; the whole together duly ticketed, with cards on every box and bag, marking the proper time for ſowing each article.

One ſhould be of Cyprian's age to know the exceſs of his joy upon this occaſion. In his mind, the little ſpot of earth which his father had aſſigned him, was as great as monarchs think their kingdoms; and whatever hours of relaxation his preceptor let him take, and which he ſpent before in folly, were now taken up in cultivating his domain.

One day, when he came in from doing ſomething about his garden he forgot to ſhut the gate. A hen was pecking near the ſpot, and took it in her head to go a hunting on his grounds. The flower-bed had been ſtrewed but lately with a layer of the richeſt mould, and was conſequently quite full of worms.

The hen, charmed with ſuch delicious fare, began to ſcratch the mould up, and employ her beak as well as talons to unearth the worms; and in particular, ſhe took a mighty inclination to a part, where Cyprian had, the day, before been planting ſome fine pinks.

How great therefore was the exceſs of his rage when coming back to his plantation, he beheld the door a jar, and this new-faſhioned gardener digging up his beds? Ah! ah! you impudent ſlut! ſaid he; your bones ſhall pay for this. And immediately he ſhut the door, for fear his victim ſhould eſcape, and picking up flint ſtones, ſand, clods of earth, and whatever he could lay hold of, he threw them at the bird, purſuing her all the while as cloſe as he could.

The frightened hen, at one time ran with all her ſpeed, and at another time ſtrove to fly upon the wall, but found that her wings would not befriend her in reaching ſuch a height. Unhappily, ſhe fell back more than once on Cyprian's flowers, and got her wings and feet entangled with the fineſt hyacinths.

Young Cyprian, beholding her thus embroiled, ſuppoſed that he had her faſt. Two rows of tulips ſeparated them. His anger was ſo vehement, that ſtepping over, as he meant to do, this interval of ſeparation between the hen and him, he trod them down himſelf. The hen, however, at her enemy's approach, redoubled her former
efforts, and attempted now a ſecond time to gain the wall. She roſe a great deal higher than before, yet ſtill came ſhort; but what was matter of regret for Cyprian, bore away with her from underneath as ſhe roſe, a beautiful roſe-bud-coloured ten-belled hyacinth. On this, he ſeized his rake, and flung it at the bird with all his ſtrength. The rake turned round, and while he fancied it upon the point of hitting the fugitive mark, it came down, and daſhed two panes of glaſs to pieces in a melon frame, as well as broke out two of its own teeth upon the ground.

The little Fury, made much more furious by theſe damages, had run for his ſpade, and now the combat would perhaps have had fatal conſequences for his feathered adverſary, who fatigued and giddy had crept in between a roſe-buſh and the wall, if Mr. Tiſdall, at firſt attracted to his window by the noiſe, had not made haſte to her aſſiſtance.

The moment Cyprian ſaw his father, he ſtood ſtock ſtill in evident confuſion; however he made ſhift to find his tongue at laſt, and cried out, See, papa, what ravage this vile creature has committed in my garden.

Had you ſhut the door replied his father with an affected indifference, this ravage would not have been made. I ſaw your whole behaviour. Are you not aſhamed of having put forth all your ſtrength againſt a harmleſs hen? She has no reaſon to conduct herſelf, and though ſhe has rooted up your pinks, it was not with a wiſh to do you any damage, but to get her ordinary food. Now, Cyprian, ſhould you have put yourſelf thus into a paſſion, if ſhe had ſcratched up nothing but as many nettle roots? And how can ſhe diſtinguiſh between pinks and nettles? It is yourſelf alone that are to blame for all this havock. With precaution you would certainly have driven her out ſo that ſhe might do no further miſchief; and in that caſe, neither your rake, nor my melon frame, would have gone to ruin, or your loſs have exceeded that of a few flowers. Therefore you alone are puniſhable, ſo that were I to cut a branch off from this hazle-tree, and with it make you ſuffer juſt what you deſigned the hen ſhould ſuffer—which of us would act with the greateſt juſtice? I ſhall not, however, go to this extremity, purpoſely to ſhew you that we may all ſuppreſs our reſentment, if we think proper. Notwithſtanding, for the damage done to my melon frame,
I ſhall deduct as much as will repair it, from the arrears of your allowance in my hands; for I am not to ſuffer through your raſhneſs.
Cyprian, upon this, withdrew much abaſhed, and all day durſt ſcarcely lift his eyes up, while before his father.

On the morrow, Mr. Tiſdall propoſed a walk, and aſked if he deſired to join him. Cyprian followed, but oppreſſed with ſadneſs which he ſought in vain to hide. His father ſaw it, and affecting a degree of wonder, wiſhed to know why he appeared ſo grievouſly dejected.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: Have I not the greateſt cauſe to be dejected? For this whole month paſt, I have denied myſelf ſo many pleaſures, merely to buy ſomething for my ſiſter. I had ſaved ten ſhillings, with which I thought to purchaſe her a pretty hat; but muſt give the half of it perhaps to have your melon frame repaired.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: I dare ſay, you would have been delighted to oblige your ſiſter, but my melon frame, however, muſt be paid for firſt. This leſſon will teach you in future not to yield yourſelf up to the miſchiefs of reſentment which in general aggravates the firſt misfortune happening to us.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: Ah! you may depend upon it, ſir, I will never leave the garden-door open again, or take revenge upon a hen for what would be my own omiſſion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: But, pray tell me, do you fancy that, in this vaſt univerſe, hens only have it in their power to do you damage?

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: O! no, no; for look ye, not above a week ago I left my map upon the table while I went a walking, and my little ſiſter coming into the room, with a pen and ink ſo blotted it all over, that no one could diſtinguiſh Europe from America.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: Then it is prudent to ſecure yourſelf againſt the miſchiefs that you may ſuffer from your fellow-creatures.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: It is ſo, papa.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p:
Without deſiring in the leaſt to give you a diſtaſte of life, I can aſſure you that you will have to ſuffer many diſagreeable affairs, and thoſe a deal more prejudicial to you, than the miſchiefs cauſed by the hen. Mankind always ſeek their intereſt and their pleaſures,
juſt as hens ſeek worms; and they will do ſo at the hazard of your intereſts, as hens will at the hazard of your flowers.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: I ſee it plainly, ſir, by Bella's behaviour; ſince the little pleaſure that ſhe received from ſcribbling on a bit of paper, has occaſioned me the loſs of an extremely uſeful map.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: But could you not have avoided this loſs, by putting up your map before you left the apartment?

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: Then think for the future to conduct yourſelf ſo, that no body may have power to do you any real miſchief; but if after all, in ſpite of your precaution, you ſhould be ſo unlucky as to receive an injury, conſider how you may endure it, ſo as not to render the firſt wrong ſtill more prejudicial.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: Ay, papa; but how muſt I endure it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: With indifference, if it be a ſlight injury, but, on the other hand, if a great one, with courage. Now that we are by ourſelves, I dare propoſe you as an example the conduct that I purſue towards Mr. Hotham.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: Pray don't ſpeak of him, papa. Theſe two years paſt, he takes no notice of you whenever you meet each other, and there cannot be a falſity that he will not ſay to prejudice you in the opinion of the world.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: And do you know what urges him to ſuch behaviour?

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: That I never yet durſt aſk you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p: Nothing but for the preference which I obtained reſpecting an employ that my father had ſo worthily filled up for five and thirty years, and to which he had affectionately formed me by the moſt diligent inſtruction. Mr. Hotham had no title to the poſt, except his ignorance and ſelf-ſufficiency. My right ſucceeded, notwithſtanding all his intereſt, and therefore am I honoured with his calumny and hatred.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: Ah! papa, were I as big as you, I'd teach him better manners.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tiſdall.
sp.p:
Quite the contrary, I let him go on railing at me juſt as he thinks fit. The conduct which you ſhould have purſued, when you were injured by the hen, I faithfully purſue towards him. The pinks that ſhe ſcratched up by the roots, in ſeeking for worms, may
repreſent the reputable character that I bear, and which in order to gratify the worm of Envy that gnaws him, he labours to undo. Were I to ſeek the means of puniſhing him, I ſhould trample under foot that deference and reſpect which I owe to myſelf, as you trod under foot your tulips. The me • on frame and rake which you damaged, are that wealth and peace of mind that I ſhould deſtroy, by hurrying on to vengeance. Taught in future by the loſſes that you have ſuffered, you will ſhut the garden door, in order to keep the hen out. Taught too by the wicked diſpoſition of my enemy, I lay, by means of proper conduct on my part, an inſuperable barrier between us. Thus inacceſſible to his vindictive attempts, I enjoy the comforts of my moderation, while he ſpends himſelf in thoſe attempts, and will in time experience the compunction of his evil conſcience. Could his inſults vex me, I ſhould make myſelf the victim that he would ſacrifice, and be reproached for imbecility, by every worthy character of my acquaintance; while on the other hand the inſenſibility that I manifeſt for his injurious treatment yields him to his own contempt, and, in the boſom of good men, keeps up the reputation that I have gained among them.

sp.speaker: Cyprian.
sp.p: Ah! papa, what trouble may I not ſhun hereafter, by remembering every thing that you have taught me!

Theſe laſt words were hardly uttered, when they found themſelves at home, without imagining that they had been ſo near it. Their diſcourſe, for the remainder of the day, was a continuation of the paſt; and bed-time being come, they ſeparated quite content with one another. Cyprian ſunk to ſlumber, with a boſom full of gratitude for the inſtruct on which he had juſt received, and Mr. Tiſdall with one poſſeſſing all the ſatisfaction that a good father cannot but experience, who is ſenſible that he has done ſomething to promote his offspring's happineſs.

p.hi: Louiſa, with Leonora her ſiſter, are diſcovered working in their room: Sophy ſtands by Louiſa; Clara enters to them.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: HARD at work! How melancholy you all look! I thought to find you at play upon the ſnow. Come, come, and ſee the trees: they are powdered juſt for all the world like—what d'ye call 'ems.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No: we would not leave our work for any pleaſure that you could name to us.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh, I frequently leave mine for nothing—But you have not long I hope, to ſit here moping.

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: We were moping, as you call it, all yeſterday; and have been at it again ever ſince the clock ſtruck ſeven.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: My ſtars! I was not up till ten: and in the name of goodneſs! what poſſeſſes you, to work at ſuch a rate?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: If you but knew, Clara, for whom we are, I am ſure, you would willingly make make one amongſt us.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Indeed, I would not, Louiſa, were it even for myſelf.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yourſelf! I ſhould not work, thus late and early, with ſuch ſpirits, for myſelf: nor you, I fancy, Leonora.

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Sopby.
sp.p: Gueſs who 'tis for.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Not for yourſelf, you ſay. It muſt be for your dolls then.—I have gueſſed it! Have I not?

sp.speaker: Louiſa,
sp.p: Yes, yes; look here, and ſee if theſe will fit a doll.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: How! how! Why, here's a dreſs complete! Which of you is going to be married?

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: Did you ever hear the like? a jacket to be married in! The girl is crazy, ſhe will never gueſs.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Well then, I'll tell you who 'tis for. You know theſe two poor children, that have nothing on but rags?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What! that poor woman who has lately loſt her huſband, and cannot get a bit of bread?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yes, the ſame; it is for her poor children that we are ſo hard at work.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But you know, your mama and mine both ſent her money.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: So they did; but there were debts to pay, and bread to buy. As for clothes—

sp.speaker: Leoncra.
sp.p: We have taken that upon us.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But, my dear, why not much rather ſend them ſome of your own old clothes? You would, in that caſe, ſpare yourſelves a deal of trouble.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: How you talk! As if our clothes were fit for ſuch ſmall children!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: That I know: they would have been too big, and dragged upon the ground at leaſt a quarter of a yard; but then, their mother might have made them leſs herſelf.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: She cannot.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And why not?

sp.speaker: Leonora,
sp.p: Becauſe her parents never taught her how to uſe her needle.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Now, as we are rather ready at it, we deſired mama to let us have ſome dimity, and other ſtuff, and to out us out the neceſſary patterns, promiſing to do the reſt ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: And when the whole is finiſhed, we ſhall viſit the poor woman with it, that her children may be dreſſed a little warmly this cold weather.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Now, my dear, you know the reaſon why we won't go play upon the ſnow.

sp.speaker: Clara
sp.p: I'll work a little with you.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ay, I ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: No, no; we have almoſt done.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But, Leonora, why deprive her of ſo great a pleaſure? Look you here, my friend; complete this hem: but you muſt ſew it carefully.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: If not, my ſiſter will undo it; I am ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What you muſt ſpeak too then, Mrs. Whipperſnapper; juſt as if you knew what is going forward.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: How, Clara? I aſſure you, Sophy has aſſiſted us ſurprizingly. It was ſhe that held the ſtuff while we were cutting it, handed us the pincuſhion, and picked us up our thimbles when they fell. Here, my little dear, take the ſciffars: Leonora wants them.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Look, dear Louiſa, have I done this right?

sp.speaker: Leonora,
sp.p: Oh fie! theſe ſtitches are a mile too long, and all awry.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: True, they would not hold. But ſtay; I'll give you ſomething elſe.—Here, paſs this bobbin through the jacket collar.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Ay, ay; I ſhall ſucceed better in this.

sp.speaker: Leonora,
sp.p: See! ſee! how ſhe ſets about it!—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ah, that's all my fault, who did not tell her how it ſhould be done.—See here, my dear Clara,—in this manner.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I was never taught to do ſo much as you; and that is the reaſon that I am ſo awkward.

sp.speaker: Leonora,
sp.p: Oh, I eaſily believe you.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But do not vex her, ſiſter: ſhe has done her beſt. Hold, let me look a little. How! you have paſſed the bobbin through already. Look ye, Leonora.

sp.speaker: Leonora
sp.p: What a pity, it will not ſtir. A mighty clever needle-woman, truly! ſhe does nothing elſe but make us work.

sp.speaker: Clara
sp.p: Alas! I know no better.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Do not afflict yourſelf: you have the beſt of wills; and we have nothing more to boaſt. It ſhall be quickly put to rights. I will do it for you. There; the matter is ſettled. Have you finiſhed, Leonora?

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: Only one more ſtitch:—and then, to cut the thread off.—There: now I will make up the parcel. (She is preparing to do ſo, when Mrs. Vincent enters.)

sp.speaker: Sopby.
sp.p: Here is mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: Well, my dears; how do you go on? Perhaps you wiſh for my aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No, mama; we have finiſhed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: Have you? Let me ſee a little.—Very well indeed!—What, my Sophy! I am afraid, you thought the time tedious.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Oh, not I, mama: I always had ſome little thing to do; aſk my ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yes, indeed: we ſhould not have ended ſo quickly, but for her aſſiſtance. She has never quitted us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: That was well done. Ah! here is our little neighbour too, Miſs Clara. She muſt have helped you a good deal.

sp.speaker: Leonora,
sp.p: She tried; but—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Indeed, we had almoſt finiſhed when ſhe came.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: She made a ſtitch or two, but ſhe hardly knows more than I: if you had but ſeen, mama, how crooked—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Hold your tongue!
Come; ſince you have been ſo very diligent, I have joyful news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: What, mama?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: The two poor children and their mother are below. I will ſend you up the little ones, that you may dreſs them, and enjoy the aſtoniſhment of their mother, when ſhe obſerves them ſo much altered.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ah, mama, how you increaſe our pleaſures!

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: Shall I go and fetch them up?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: Yes; follow me: and you ſhall come back with them. In the interim, I will have a little converſation with the mother, and contrive how ſhe may find out ſome employment for the time to come, and earn a little money. (She goes out with Sophy.)
Stay you here with us, Clara: we ſhall want your help; and you muſt have ſome buſineſs at our toilet.

sp.speaker: Clara,
sp.p: Ah! my friend, you have a good heart! I ſee that plainly.

sp.speaker: Lionora.
sp.p: I have had a fling or two at you, Clara. Lo • a makes me bluſh, and therefore I entreat your pardon.

sp.speaker: Clara,
sp.p: Yes, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Louſa.
sp.p: I hear the children coming up. (Sophy enters, bringing in the little girls, Madge and Joan)

sp.speaker: Sophy,
sp.p: How ſurprized they will be. I have not told them any thing about it.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You did well: their pleaſure will be the greater, and ours likewiſe.

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: I ſhall take Madge.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I Joan.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And Sophy and myſelf will hold the pincuſhions. (They begin to undreſs them.)

sp.speaker: Madge,
sp.p: We are cold enough already. Will you take away the little clothes that we have left?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Do not be afraid, poor thing! come hither. You ſhall ſee. A little this way towards the fire.—You are almoſt dead with cold.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: We have not warmed ourſelves to-day.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Theſe ſine new clothes, are they for us?

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Oh bleſs me! what will mother ſay? She will take us for your ſiſters; we ſhall be ſo fine!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And you ſhall be our ſiſters for the time to come: ſo never call us any otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Oh, good young lady, we are your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Let me have your arm—The other.—But how ſhort it is! it only reaches to her knees. Well, hairbrains! (to Leonora) this is like you! Do not you ſee that you have handed me the little jacket?

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: So I have indeed: for my part, I was puzzled likewiſe. Madge's feet were covered, and I could not ſee her head. We need but change. There is Joan's.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Let us be as quick as poſſible; and in the mean time, Sophy, do you run and bid mama come up.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: I am gone. (She goes out.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ah, now all is right. Turn round.—Once more. Very well: and now, take one another by the hand, and walk acroſs the room before us. (The children do ſo, and ſurvey themſelves with pleaſure.)

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: How extremely well they fit! they are quite pretty! and there is only one thing wanted. (To Madge.) Here is my handkerchief.—Blow hard. (To Joan.) Now you.—What elſe?—If you had time to dreſs their hair.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No, no, my dear Clara; it is much better hanging looſely. Leonora, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Leonora.
sp.p: A comb, however, to untangle it, would not be much amiſs. I will do that, Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Sophy,
sp.p: Here is mama. (Mrs. Vinrent enters with the mother of the children.)

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Oh, heavens! what do I ſee? Are theſe my children? O my generous lady! (falling down at Mrs. Vincent's feet.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent,
sp.p: My good friend, it is not to me that you are indebted for this happineſs. My children wiſhed to make a trial of their ſkill in needle-work, and I permitted them to do ſo. (Examining the children's jackets.) Not ſo bad, conſidering a firſt eſſay; you might almoſt ſet up for yourſelves.

sp.speaker: The Mother,
sp.p: My charming ladies, let me thank you. God will recompenſe your kindneſs, for I cannot. (Perceiving Clara at a diſtance) Pardon me, my little lady; I did not ſee you; otherwiſe I ſhould have paid you alſo my acknowledgments.

sp.speaker: Clara,
sp.p: No, no. I had no hand in this day's buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: Do not afflict yourſelf upon that account; my dear. By ſighing, you will get nothing; but by ſtedfaſtly reſolving, every thing. However, tell me; do not you think it uſeful and delightful for a young lady, like you, to accuſtom herſelf betimes to work of ſome ſort or other?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Think ſo? Certainly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: Of what real pleaſure, even at preſent, are you not deprived, by having hitherto neglected an employment ſo adapted to your ſex and age?

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Dear little lady, learn betimes, if you would be conſidered provident or prudent, to love work; or it will ſoon be too late. I ſhould be very happy now, had any one but given me ſuch a leſſon in my childhood. I could now have got my br • ad, and been of uſe to thoſe dependant on me for ſupport, inſtead of being burthenſome to worthy people.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p:
Truly, my good friend, it would have been much happier for you, I muſt own, although I ſhould have loſt the pleaſure of aſſiſting you. But you are yet full young enough to make up for loſt time, by application to ſome honeſt labour. Children, you muſt know, I have procured her ſome employment at a weaver's in the neighbourhood; and when ſhe happens to have
nothing to do there, ſhe is to come and work here in the garden.

sp.speaker: Sophy.
sp.p: I am very glad of that; for I will go too, and help her, if I am able.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: With reſpect to Madge and Joan, I mean that my houſe ſhall be their ſchool; and you have both, (to Louiſa and Leonora,) deſerved to be their miſtreſſes in work and reading.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And may I be their aſſiſtant, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Vincent.
sp.p: With all my heart, if your mama conſents; in which caſe, you and Sophy ſhall endeavour to outdo each other. (To the poor woman.) My good friend, are you contented that matters ſhould be as I have ſettled?

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Contented? My benevolent and generous lady, I ſhall owe you all my happineſs, and that, too, of my deſtitute and friendleſs children. Dear good angels, give God thanks, for having bleſſed you with ſo careful a mamma, who trains you up thus betimes to diligence. You ſee, it is the ſource of comfort to yourſelves and to us too.

div.p: ⸪ Omitted here, "THE LOVE OF GOD AND OF OUR PARENTS," a Piece that indeed will not well bear to be tranſlated into Engliſh.

div.head: CHARACTERS.
div.p: The SCENE is at the entrance of a grove, before the houſe of Captain Greville, ſomewhat diſtant from the road.

p.hi: Eugenia is diſcovered ſitting on a trunk, and picking ſtrawberries. Beſide her lies her ſtraw bat to hold the ſtrawberries when picked. Douglas brings her more in his. Both bats are neatly lined with leaves.

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: LOOK ye, ſiſter, we ſhall quickly have enough.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: I do not know, Douglas, how I ſhall diſpoſe of mine: my hat is too full already.

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: Mary Anne cannot be long before ſhe brings the buſhel; and indeed ſhe might have gone into the houſe, found one, and returned in much leſs time than this. However, in the interval, Eugenia, put them in your apron.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Yes, yes; that would make fine work indeed. To ſpot it all from top to bottom! What do you ſuppoſe mama would ſay? and therefore I have thought of ſomething elſe. Your hat is biggeſt; ſo I will add my ſtrawberries to yours, and you ſhall go and gather more, while I am picking theſe.

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: Well ſaid, indeed; and in the interim, Mary Anne cannot fail to come, and then we ſhall have got enough.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: When they are all together, we ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: What is over when the baſkets are filled, we will take ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: I think, we ſhall not have much appetite to taſte them afterwards. Ah, brother! it is the laſt time that we ſhall eat with our papa this year, and who can tell whether we ſhall ever ſee him more.

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: Oh! do not be dejected, ſiſter. Every one is not killed in a battle.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Oh frightful war! if men were not ſo wicked; but would love each other, juſt as we do—

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: Mighty fine, indeed! And do not we quarrel every day for trifles? We each think ourſelves in the right; and frequently it would puzzle any one to find which is. It is juſt the ſame among grown men.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: They ought at leaſt, then, to be friends again, as ſoon as we are. Our worſt quarrels never come to bloodſhed.

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: No; becauſe our parents ſettle them: but men, Eugenia, are not children; and won't let themſelves be governed, if they have but arms. And in fact, is it right that we ſhould ſuffer any one to injure us, without reſiſting?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: You are always talking like a ſoldier!

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: A good reaſon why; becauſe I am to be one. Look ye, ſiſter; notwithſtanding any thing that you ſay againſt it, war is a very charming thing. Without it, how do you imagine that we ſhould live; would our papa's little fortune be ſufficient to ſupport us? But do not weep. You grieve me.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Let me weep, dear brother, while we are alone. I had much rather do ſo here, than in the preſence of papa, for I know, it would afflict him.

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: Come, come; dry your eyes, and ſet to work for ſome amuſement. I will go and fill your hat.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Go that way; we have left none hereabouts. (Douglas goes out, and after a moment's ſilence, ſhe goes on.) I would I were but learned enough, that I might pray to God, for he would hear me. Or at leaſt, if I were big enough, I would go to court, and fall before the king; and he, I am ſure, would grant me my papa's diſmiſſion, when I begged and prayed him to oblige me. He has ſerved his country long enough, I think. (She ſets about picking her ſtrawberries again.)

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Yonder is the houſe where we were told Captain Greville lives: he will be very much ſurprized and pleaſed with what I bring him; a diſmiſſion from the ſervice with ſuch honour. But, what charming little girl is this? I will ſtop and have a little converſation with her; ſo do not you addreſs me by my name. (To Eugenia, tapping her upon the ſhoulder.) Why, you are very hard at work, I ſee, my pretty child.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Oh! ſir, you frightened me.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: I aſk your pardon then, my dear. I did not mean to do ſo. And for whom are you preparing all theſe ſtrawberries? They cannot but be very fine, I think, as they are picked by ſuch a plump and ſnowy hand.

sp.speaker: Eugenia,
sp.p: I beg, then, you will take ſome, ſir. Do not be afraid; for they are very clean. I only wiſh I had a better plate to put them into. (Lord C takes two or three, as does the officer.)

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: I never taſted any better: do you ſell them, little dear?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: No, ſir; though you were to give me—I cannot tell how much.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: You are in the right: they are above all value, being gathered by ſo ſweet a little hand.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Fie! ſir, how you talk! no, it is not for that: they ſhould be at your ſervice, were they not intended for (wiping her eyes) my dear papa. We have not gathered any for • m yet this ſeaſon; and perhaps, theſe are to be the laſt that he will taſte.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: What, my dear, he is ill then; and you think that he will die?

sp.speaker: The Officer.
sp.p: His illneſs, however, it is to be hoped, is not yet quite deſperate, ſince he thinks of eating ſtrawberries.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: No, not that. It is true, indeed, he has been troubled with the rheumatiſm, all laſt winter, to a very great degree; and is not yet quite cured. But cured or not, he muſt ſet out to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: And pray why is his departure then ſo needful?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Oh, becauſe his regiment then goes through the village; and he muſt join it on the march.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: His regiment?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord Cornwallis's, that is going to America.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: I would lay you any wager, this is one of Captain Greville's children.

sp.speaker: Eugenia,
sp.p: Yes, that is my papa's name.—Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Know him? Why, the gentleman and I are both his comrades.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: What! and is the regiment ſo near then?— Will it go through the town to-day?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: No, not till to-morrow. We are come, my dear, before it; and—and— (aſide to the officer.) What excuſe can I invent to ſerve my purpoſe?—And a wheel belonging to our carriage being broke hard by, we thought to get a little ſhade here, while it was mending. And now every thing, I fancy, muſt be ſet to rights. This path, I take it, leads directly to the road again.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: No, ſir; it takes you to the village.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: And the village, I ſuppoſe, belongs to your papa?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Belongs to him? I wiſh, indeed, he were ſo rich: he has nothing but a little cottage, with a garden, this ſmall grove, and yonder meadow. When he is not at the regiment, he paſſes all his time here with us.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: He was ill then, in the winter?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Yes indeed, ſir, to our ſorrow; and he could not move a limb. Beſides, a wound which he received many years ago, below the temple, has broke out afreſh. And now that he is almoſt well, he muſt be forced to go again, to meet with new misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: In ſuch a ſituation, why does not he ſell out? He might procure ſufficient atteſtations from the ſurgeon.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Oh, mama did that in private for him; but her letters never yet were anſwered. Certainly the king refuſes to believe her; or perhaps, that Lord Cornwallis who commands the regiment, is ſo cruel—

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p:
Truly, I believe, my Lord Cornwallis would not like to loſe ſo good an officer as your papa, by whoſe

inſtructions I myſelf and all the younger officers may learn ſo much.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: And yet, you do not appear ſo very young; but are your papa and mama ſtill living?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Do you doubt it?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Oh, I warrant you, they cried at parting with you. How could they conſent to loſe you? I remember how much grief it cauſed mama and us, when firſt my eldeſt brother went abroad to ſtudy; and that is nothing in compariſon of war.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: I cannot tell that; for I have left them after many ſeparations; in which caſe it is nothing to leave one another. And beſides, when firſt I went to camp, my father went with me.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Did he? Oh, thoſe fathers that are ſoldiers themſelves, are a little hard, I can tell you; but yet that is not the caſe with my papa. He is ſo indulgent! Why, a child is ſcarce ſo gentle! It is upon the point of honour alone that he can never be perſuaded; ſo that after all, I fancy he himſelf is to blame, and nobody elſe, for his remaining ſtill in the ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Ay indeed? How is that?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Becauſe he never aſked for his diſmiſſion. He is ever ſaying, people would imagine him a coward, ſhould he quit the ſervice during war. He only wiſhes that he may always have but ſtrength enough to ſit on horſeback; and then, he ſays, he will part with every drop of blood he has, to ſerve his country. Well he will have his wiſh one time or other, but we poor children, then, ſhall be without a father.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Recollect, your father has been hitherto preſerved from danger; and why ſhould he not continue ſtill as ſafe? It is not every muſquet that hits.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: But thoſe that do, commonly kill their man; and in the number, may there not be one that will reach papa?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: That is true indeed: but what ſweet little lady is this?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: My ſiſter Mary Anne.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Eugenia, Lord Cornwallis, the Officer, Mary Anne.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: So, Mary Anne, you are come at laſt, I ſee; and where have you been ſtaying?

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Why, mama would make me help her to do up papa's portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Where is the baſket? let me have it, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Have you gathered ſtrawberries enough to fill it?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee. (emptying the hat.) Your pardon, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Oh, do not mind us. (Whiſpering the Officer.) What lovely children!

sp.speaker: Mary Anne,
sp.p: Who may theſe be!

sp.speaker: Eugenia,
sp.p: Officers in Lord Cornwallis's regiment.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Do they come to fetch papa?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: No, no: they are before the regiment, which will not go through the village till to-morrow, as papa expected.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Ah! would all the officers, together with the regiment, were at Jericho.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Speak lower, Mary Anne. If the gentlemen ſhould hear you?

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Let them hear me, if they like it. What! they come to take away papa, and ſhall not we have leave to make complaint?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Methinks, we are not looked upon very favourably here.

sp.speaker: The Officer.
sp.p: Then my lord why do not you diſcover yourſelf, and mention the good news that you bring their father?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: No. Their openneſs delights me; and the affection that they evince in favour of their parents, raviſhes my heart.

sp.speaker: Eugenia,
sp.p: Poor Douglas is hard at work, while we are chattering here without once thinking of him. I will go and help him. Mary Anne, ſtay you here, and take care how you ſpeak before theſe gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Go, go; I know what is proper.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: This is my ſiſter, Mary Anne: I preſent her to you, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne,
sp.p: Your ſervant, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: She has a countenance as reſolute as yours is timid.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: She will ſtay here to entertain you, gentlemen; for I muſt run and help my brother to gather ſtrawberries; ſo that all of us may go back the ſooner to papa. Will you permit me to inform him of your viſit?—He will be very happy to receive you.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: No; he will not be very happy to receive you, nor we neither; we ſhould rather be pleaſed were we left alone at preſent.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: I hope, your kindneſs will excuſe this little mad-cap.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Oh yes, to be ſure! Excuſe me? Why theſe gentlemen are ſenſible that little girls, when ſtrangers are at table, muſt not ſpeak a word; and I have twenty thouſand things to tell papa at parting, which will otherwiſe go near to break my heart.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Dear children, do not fear any thing: you ſhall not be diſturbed by us in your delightful converſation. (Eugenia makes a grateful curtſy, and withdraws.)

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: But pray tell me, gentlemen, what reaſon has the king for thus taking away a good papa from us poor children? Does he think that we do not want one to bring us up?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: No, no; but then do you think that he does not want good ſoldiers, to go abroad and fight?

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: And what neceſſity for fighting? Or ſuppoſe that there ſhould be any, ſurely our papa, in ſtaying at home to give his children a good education, would not be uſeleſs to his country.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: No, indeed; eſpecially, my pretty Mary Anne, if his other little ones improve as much as you do.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: I believe you jeſt. I know that I am thought a little forward in the family; and I have heard it ſaid, that if I had but a cockade, I could not fail to make a tolerable ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! A little Amazon! You would become a perfect hero!

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: I can tell you, if I had only a ſword, I would not be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Nay, if that be all, here is mine. I will arm you with it.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Do. I ſhould be very glad.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.stage: (preſenting the ſword, and ſtooping to ſalute her.)
sp.p: This is the firſt ceremony.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne,
sp.p: Softly! ſoftly! I beſeech you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Oh! you are a charming child!

sp.speaker: Mary Anne,
sp.p: Brother! ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Mighty well, Miſs Soldier; you are afraid of me then, I ſee!

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: I afraid of you! Oh no. But do not, however, come too near, or I ſhall run and fetch papa. Papa is an officer as well as you are, and will not ſuffer any one to hurt his little Mary Anne.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Heaven forbid that I ſhould deſign to hurt you! It was only done in joke.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Lord Cornwallis, the Officer, Mary Anne, Eugenia, Douglas.

sp.speaker: Douglas,
sp.p: You cried out juſt now, Mary Anne! I am come to your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Againſt us, my little friend?

sp.speaker: Douglas.
sp.p: Againſt any one that hurts my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Thank you, brother; but I did not mean to cry out quite ſo loud, and have no need of your aſſiſtance; for, you ſee, I have diſarmed one. However, ſir, (returning Lord C. his ſword,) for this once I grant you quarter. But do not come too near in future. I believe you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Why, I vow, you are an extraordinary little creature!

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: I am charmed to hear you talk ſo; but, gentlemen, at laſt we have gathered ſtrawberries enough to ſhare ſome with you. (Preſenting them the buſhel.) Take a ſew, let me requeſt you.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: No, indeed; we do not intend to touch them; they have a deſtination more reſpectable than that we ſhould think of making free with any.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Thoſe that you take will all be from our ſhare: and there will be no harm done, ſhould we go without. You are in papa's own regiment; and it is ſitting that we ſhou'd treat you with as much reſpect as we are able.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne,
sp.stage: (taking a noſegay from her boſom and preſenting it to Lord C.)
sp.p: Ah! on that account I will beg you to accept this noſegay. I had gathered it for myſelf. Papa and mama already have had one a-piece, or I could not have given you this: but it belongs to me, ſir, and I give it you.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: And I, my little dear, accept it with the greateſt pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: It is ſomewhat faded by the ſun; but if you will ſtay a little, I will go gather you ſome jaſmin, violets and jonquils in my garden.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: Mary Anne, you remember, I ſuppoſe, the roſe-buſh juſt before my window? You may gather all the roſes that are blown upon it.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Well, ſir, ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Would you have that kindneſs, my dear child? But no, I thank you; for the pleaſure of converſing with you entertains me more than all the roſes in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: A thought ſtrikes me. Poſſibly, you know what way an officer ſhould take to quit the ſervice honourably. Could you not afford us ſome good counſel to procure papa's diſmiſſion?

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
sp.p: If you could, we ſhould be very glad to give you every thing in our power.

sp.speaker: Douglas,
sp.stage: (who has hitherto amuſed himſelf by playing with the hilt of Lord C • 's ſword, and looking at his uniform.)
sp.p: O yes! if you could only tell us how to keep papa at home, my drum, ſpontoon, cartouch box, and accoutrements, ſhould all be yours.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne,
sp.p: And I will give you free'y, what you ſought juſt now to take by force.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: So many charming things at once! Believe me, if I did but know—

sp.speaker: Eugenia,
sp.p: You did but know! So then we only make things worſe, and grieve you that you cannot be of ſervice to us.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Oh! I do not give up ſo ſoon. My Lord Cornwallis, colonel of the regiment, will very ſoon paſs this way. Well then, we three will go and throw ourſelves before him, hang upon his clothes, and not let him go until he has granted our deſire.

sp.speaker: Eugenia.
