sp.speaker: Elder Danby,
sp.stage: (juſt before he ſteps into the cloſet.)
sp.p: Well: have you finiſhed? Oh make haſte. You take a deal of time. What miſchief are you whiſpering to each other?

stage.hi: At this inſtant the groom preſents himſelf at the door; he has a lighted torch in one hand, and a ſtick beneath it in the other, with a large fullbottomed wig upon it. He is covered head and all, with Mr. Jephſon's gown, which trails along upon the ground behind him. Frank beckons him to ſtay a little at the entrance, while he is b • ding Roberts.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.stage: (putting Roberts in the middle of the room.)
sp.p: How many horſes in your father's ſtable?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Three; black, white and grey.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Turn about— pretending to be angry with the others.) Be quiet pray, young ladies, and not quit your places till the game is begun.—Turn about three times, and catch whom you may.
The ghoſt! the ghoſt! Run, Roberts, for your life.
(He claps the door to violently, hides himſelf behind the Grown, and ſpeaking through the trumpet, ſays,) It is you then that come to ſteal my treaſure?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.stage: (trembling with fear, and not daring to pull off the bandage.)
sp.p: Fie! fire! Danby! where are you, Frank? murder! murder! Dorinda!

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: I have ſcared them all away.—Pull off your bandage, and look at me.

div.stage: Roberts, without pulling off the bandage, puts both hands before his face, retiring as the ghoſt advances on him.)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pull it off, I ſay—

div.stage: Roberts makes ſhift to pull the bandage down, which falis about his neck. He dares not lift his eyes up; but at laſt when he chſerves the ghoſt, be ſcreams out, and has not power to move)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I know you well, your name is Roberts.

div.stage: Roberts hearing this, runs up and down to get away: he finds the door ſhut faſt, falls down upon his knees, holds out his hands, and turns away his head)

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What you think to eſcape me, do you?

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: I have done nothing to you. You were never robbed by me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Never robbed by you? You are capable of any villainy! Who ſquirts at people in the ſtreet? Who faſtens rabbits' tails behind their backs? Who fiſhes for their wigs? Who lames poor dogs and cats? Who ſticks up pins in chairs to prick his friends when they ſit down! And who has in his pocket even now, a maſk to frighten two poor little children?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: I have done all this! indeed I own it! but for heaven's ſake pardon me, and I will not do ſo any more.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Who will anſwer for you?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Thoſe that you have frightened away, if you will but call them.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do you promiſe me yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Yes, yes; upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well then, I take pity on you: but remember, had it been my pleaſure, I might eaſily fly away with you through the window.

div.stage: Here the phantom ſhakes his torch, which gives a glare like lightning, and then goes out. Roberts almoſt ſwooning with terror, falls down on his face.)

div.head: SCENE the laſt.
div.stage: Roberts, Frank, the Groom, Mr. Jephſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon,
sp.stage: (entering with a candle in his hand.)
sp.p: What is all this diſturbance?

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: It is not I that make it. Pray, pray, do not come near me!

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon,
sp.p: Who can this be on the ground?

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: You know me well enough, and have already taken pity on me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: I already taken pity on you!

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: It was not I that robbed you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: Robbed me! what does all this mean? do not I know you, maſter Roberts?—

sp.speaker: Roberts.
sp.p: Yes, yes; that is my name, good ghoſt: ſo pray do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed! why in ſuch a poſture? He puts down the light, holds out his hand and lifts him up.)

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.stage: (ſtruggling firſt of all, but knowing Mr. Jephſon afterwards.)
sp.p: Mr. Jephſon, is it you? his features brighten) He is gone then! is he? he looks round about him, ſees the ghoſt and turns away again.) There, there he ſtands! —the phantom!—don't you ſee him?

div.stage: Frank brings the children from the cloſet. Laura and younger Danby are frightened at the groom's appearance; but the reſt burſt out a laughing.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: Well! what ſignifies all this?

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: Let me explain the whole, papa. This phantom is your groom; and we have put on him your wig and gown.

sp.speaker: The Groom,
sp.p: Yes, ſir, it is I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: An odd ſort of ſport this, Frank!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: True; but aſk the company if maſter Roberts has not well deſerved to be thus frightened. He deſigned to frighten Laura and Danby: I only wiſhed to hinder him. Let him but ſhew the frightful maſk that he has about him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon,
sp.p: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Roberts,
sp.p: I cannot deny it: here it is, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: You have met with nothing, then, but what you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Dorinda.
sp.p: We perſuaded Miſs Lucy to permit her brother to make uſe of this device in order to puniſh Roberts.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: If you knew beſides, ſir, all the other tricks that he meant to play us—

sp.speaker: Mr. Jephſon.
sp.p: What, ſir, is this the ſample that you give us of your behaviour, the firſt time you ſet foot withinmy doors? You have been diſreſpectful to me in the perſon of my children, who were pleaſed with the expectation of having you as their gueſt. You have been diſreſpectful to theſe ladies, whom I need not ſay you ſhould have honoured and regarded. So be gone! Your father, when he comes to know that you have been thus turned out of doors, will ſee how neceſſary it is to correct the vices of your heart. I will not permit your deteſtable example to corrupt my children. Go, and never let me ſee you here again! Roberts is confounded, and withdraws.) And you, my friends, although the circumſtances of the caſe may very poſſibly excuſe what you have done, yet never, for the time to come, indulge yourſelves in ſuch a ſport. The fears which have power to affect children at a tender age, may poſſibly be followed by the worſt conſequences during their whole life. Avenge yourſelves upon the wicked only by behaving better; and remember after the example which maſter Roberts has afforded you, that by intending harm to others, you will ofteneſt bring it down upon yourſelves.
